day of the program, and thank you to Director Tamayo and Vice President Fishman were in attendance for the closing award ceremony. This is one of those unique programs that goes out into the community and educates them to make them aware of the great opportunities that IBEW and SMUD have on the jobs that pay extremely well. The Lineman Apprenticeship program starts pay at $45/hr, and when they graduate in five years, it is almost $80/hr. And, it is not just a job, it is a career that they can go to any city, after they become certified by IBEW, they can go to any city in the United States and get a job as a lineperson. So, this is something that we are very, very proud of. But, the thing that I am especially proud of is the excitement. I was there at the graduation, and the excitement those cohorts – one of them said, “I could see myself teaching here 10 years from now.” Two of the participants had their mom there, and she said, “I am going to make sure my son studies because now he knows how to climb, but he has got to pass math and written tests. So, I am going to make sure that my son studies and is well prepared for the test.” It was great to see the excitement and dedication. One of the female cohorts was still lifting crossarms, even after the program was over because she wanted to make sure she could actually hoist that crossarm 40 feet up in the air, and it is really gratifying to see the excitement of the cohorts but also I think Vice President spoke of the camaraderie that they were building with each other within just four weeks of working and getting training on the weekends. That is very remarkable. 4) Awards. SMUD was honored with several awards this past month. We received a Silver Outage Operations Award from Chartwell for our innovative Storm Response Team initiative. As you know, after the storm last year, SMUD did a tremendous amount of work to improve how we manage outages, how we assess outages, to supply chain, to how we actually make sure the crews are here before the storm actually starts to making sure we have ample crews to respond to the forecast of what the storm damage is going to look like in the Sacramento region. We worked really hard last year not only in improving the way we respond but the way we communicate with the customers. You saw now on the SMUD website, there are multiple stages. You can report the outage, then we said we know about the outage, we are sending a crew to assess, a crew is on the way, and then now you are being repaired. So, we hard loud and clear from the Board and from our customers that when you have major storms like that, you really need to make sure you step it up on your communications with the customer, not just operations, but every step of the way to making sure that our customers are informed. # What is a Prepay?

- 2003 IRS Regulations allow for tax-exempt debt to be issued for the prepayment of natural gas/electricity to serve load
- Commodity supply agreement where buyer commits to purchase the commodity over a term, receiving a discount to the market price
- Cost of funding is lower than supplier would otherwise receive borrowing from taxable market or from using internal funding at their cost of capital
- Bond investor risk is tied to supplier and corporate guarantor (not SMUD) to make debt service payments and redeem bonds if termination events occur or bankruptcy

# Commodity Prepay Summary

  ➤ NCEA plans to issue up to $800 million of similar bonds this spring for a 6-year term that optimizes the savings that SMUD receives

- Reduces operating costs to help SMUD reach zero carbon by 2030
- Contractual provisions protect SMUD savings

**Revenues**
- Revenues from sales to customers were $227.4 million, which was $3.1 million lower than planned. The decrease is primarily due to:
  - Lower residential customer revenue of $5.5 million primarily due to lower customer usage.
  - Higher commercial sales of $1.7 million primarily due to higher customer usage.
  - Lower provision for uncollectible accounts of $0.5 million.
- Revenues under the California Global Warming Solutions Act (Assembly Bill [AB] – 32) were $10.4 million. This is due to carbon allowances sold through the state sanctioned quarterly auctions.
- Low Carbon Fuel Standard (LCFS) revenues were $2.1 million due to LCFS credit sales.
- Other electric revenues were higher due to higher transmission revenue, interconnection fees and Sacramento Power Academy revenue.
- Non-cash revenues transferred to the rate stabilization fund were $12.6 million, of which $10.4 million was for AB-32 and $2.1 million was for LCFS. AB-32 and LCFS funds are deferred until SMUD has qualified program expenses (projects that reduce carbon emissions or electric vehicle programs) to recognize revenue.
- Non-cash revenues transferred from the rate stabilization fund were $11.1 million, which is $8.8 million higher than plan. The increase is primarily due to $9.1 million of revenue recognized for AB-32 and $0.6 million of revenue recognized for LCFS.

**Commodities, Purchased Power, and Production**
- SMUD’s generation was lower by 149 GWh (10.7 percent); JPA and other generation was lower by 189 GWh (14.9 percent); and Hydro generation was higher by 40 GWh (32.3 percent).
- Purchased power expense of $53.9 million, less surplus power sales of $29.9 million, was $24.0 million, which was $1.6 million higher than planned. Due to favorable rates, year to date cost of purchased power is lower, whereas the quantity of purchased power is higher. In addition, lower market sales at lower prices are driving net purchased power higher.
- Production operations cost of $82.5 million, less surplus gas sales of $18.3 million, was $64.2 million, which was $14.5 million lower than planned.
  - Fuel costs of $61.6 million less surplus gas sales of $18.3 million, was $43.3 million, which was $12.8 million lower than planned. Thermal generation has decreased due to an unplanned outage at the Carson plant and it was more economic to replace with hydro generation and market purchases.
- The “power margin”, or sales to customers less cost of purchased power, production operations costs and gas hedges included in investment revenues was $140.8 million, which was $11.4 million higher than planned. The power margin as a percentage of sales to customers was 61.9 percent, which was 5.8 percent higher than planned. This is primarily due to lower production costs due to lower fuel costs offset by lower sales to customers.

**Other Operating Expenses**
- All other operating expenses were $162.8 million, which was $1.2 million higher than planned.
  - Transmission and distribution operations expenses were down $2.2 million primarily due to lower transmission fees as a result of using more hydro generation than plan.
  - Customer service and information expenses were down $1.8 million due to lower participation in My Energy Optimizer Partner and Peak Conserve programs, Program Managers’ charging less time than planned, and Shade Tree program moving out of Advanced Energy Solutions Portfolio.
  - Administrative & General expenses were down $2.3 million primarily due to a slower start to projects such as Agile product teams, SAP S4HANA, offset by higher administrative costs related to the February storm.
<!-- Page 1048 -->
- Public Good expenses were $2.6 million higher than planned primarily due to increased HVAC and rebate volume in the Advanced Homes Solutions program and Multi-Family Exist program. Also, increased building electrification programs and support.
- Production maintenance expenses were lower than planned due to shifting from planned maintenance to unplanned major repair at the Carson plant.
- Transmission and distribution maintenance expenses were $5.6 million higher than planned primarily due to higher costs related to the February storm response.
- Non-cash depreciation and amortization is higher by $2.1 million primarily due to higher amortization of software subscription assets.

Non-operating Revenues and Expenses
- Other revenue, net, was $58.3 million higher than planned primarily due to a business interruption insurance recovery payment of $51.4 million related to the Cosumnes Power Plant and a settlement payment of $5.8 million related to the Rancho Seco annual spent fuel settlement, and higher interest income.
